race.name: 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge
race.tagline: Three-state mountain gravel crossing Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads crossing Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional AL event. Three-state mountain terrain is unique but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge is a regional event in Mentone, northeast Alabama—crossing Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee with mountain terrain. The three-state challenge and significant climbing are unique, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Mentone provides moderate access. It's a solid regional event for Alabama cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Alabama gravel race with three-state mountain terrain. Worth it for Alabama cyclists seeking a unique three-state challenge. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Three-state mountain gravel crossing Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Alabama and want a unique three-state mountain challenge—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Cohutta, Southern Cross. For similar regional events: other AL gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Mentone has limited lodging. Fort Payne or Chattanooga have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Three-state mountain gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: Traditional 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge - Metric (63 Miles)

non_negotiables.why: Three-state mountains require solid climbing fitness (6000 feet).
AL spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.

topics.heat: Racing in AL heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Three-state mountain gravel crossing Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with unique three-state challenge.

logistics.explanation: Steve Maas's 2008 report shows decent race organization - police blocking intersections in Chattanooga, sag stops with fruit and cookies, officials recording finish times at the stadium. But the race has vanished from current calendars with no confirmed Mentone logistics or 2025 registration details available.

length.explanation: Steve Maas learned the hard way: "A lot of people go too hard climbing the first two hills and do not leave enough in the tank for the last one." His advice to pace early and save energy for Burkhalter Gap shows 65 miles creates proper strategic consequences without ultra-endurance demands. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The three climbs escalate in difficulty - Suck Mountain runs 5 miles at 4-6% gradients, Sand Mountain comes "shorter and steeper," then Burkhalter Gap hits 20-22% grades for the final 500 yards. Steve Maas saw riders walking that last pitch despite having a 28-tooth low gear. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 6000 feet over 65 miles delivers serious climbing density - nearly 100 feet per mile. The three major climbs create distinct suffering sessions rather than endless grinding, which builds character without destroying souls. Past riders called it 'challenging but very satisfying when completed' - that's honest elevation work. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Rolling terrain after climbs puts it: "The rolling stretch atop Lookout Mountain has more climbing than I recalled. Or my legs were just tired."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 76°F and lows of 57°F, with a 57% chance of rain on any given day. Alabama in cycling season means heat, humidity, and unpredictable spring weather. 'Rain or shine' policy acknowledges you might get hammered by conditions. No specific weather data for typical race dates, but Lookout Mountain region can serve up everything from perfect temps to swamp-level misery. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Pedal Wench puts it: "I've done it twice - third attempt was rained out. It's a wonderful ride, great support, and really interesting route."

altitude.explanation: Lookout Mountain region tops out around 2000 feet - basically sea level for mountain standards. Zero altitude considerations for training or performance. If you need altitude challenge, you're in the wrong state and definitely the wrong race. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Three-state riding through Lookout Mountain delivers adventure - you're crossing Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee borders on backcountry roads. The climbing creates real consequences and the rural setting keeps it wild. Past course link shows proper route planning through scenic terrain that justifies the 'mountain challenge' name.

prestige.explanation: This race has serious identity issues. The original Chattanooga version had George Hincapie's name attached and hit its 30th anniversary in 2017, then apparently vanished. Now there's some Mentone, Alabama version with zero current registration info and no confirmed 2025 dates - that's not prestige, that's confusion.

race_quality.explanation: Hard to rate quality when the race might not even exist anymore. The Chattanooga version had decent organization with Litespeed frames as KOM prizes and proper packet pickup windows, but this Mentone iteration has no confirmed details, no current registration, and no race reports. You can't deliver quality if you can't deliver certainty.

experience.explanation: 65 miles through Alabama's Lookout Mountain region hits the sweet spot for most gravel riders. Past versions included regrouping at climb tops and store stops, which keeps the social vibe alive. The 'rain or shine' policy shows commitment, but without current rider reports from Mentone, you're gambling on nostalgia.

community.explanation: Originally backed by Chattanooga Bicycle Club with leaders like Rand Cimino organizing group rides at B pace (14-16 mph). The regrouping policy kept riders together instead of creating a pure suffer-fest. But community dies when races disappear - and this Mentone version has zero visible community engagement or current participant feedback.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, tennessee's 'biggest bike ride' claim from the Chattanooga days sounds impressive until you realize it's disappeared from the calendar. No current field size data, no pro participation beyond historical Hincapie connection, no competitive depth indicators. Shallow fields happen when races can't maintain consistent scheduling. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: 65 miles and 6000 feet of climbing delivers solid bang for your buck if you can actually find registration. Past versions offered Litespeed frame prizes and decent support, but value crashes to zero when you can't even confirm the race exists. Good routes don't matter if they're not accessible.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Mentone area offers DeSoto State Park lodging and waterfront cabins that sleep 16, so group splits work. No current entry fees available, but rural Alabama typically runs cheaper than destination gravel scenes. Travel costs depend on where you're coming from - this isn't a cycling mecca. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: RideWithGPS: Traditional 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge - Metric (63 Miles)
bikeforums.net: 498360 What Were Your Best Rides 2008 A.Html

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge gravel race Mentone

videos.title: 9 Essential Tips for Riding your First Gravel Race (avoid my mistakes!)
videos.description:
I took part in my first UCI level gravel event and learnt a few lessons along the way, and also spoke to some pro gravel riders about what advice, tips and wisdom they can share with people doing their first ever gravel race or event. 

Content
00:00 My mistakes and lessons
3:41 Pro advice to riding first gravel event

Recommended products:

Get the new Insta360 X4 here https://store.insta360.com/product/x4?utm_term=INRS1KM
Buy Bikestow Stance stand here https://bit.ly/3LSZQXZ
Castelli clothing  https://bit.ly/justridebikes
Sidi shoes https://bit.ly/3tjQ8UP
HJC helmet https://bit.ly/3sRiB2Z

Join this channel to get access to perks:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCybgi4WCjGaoEEVjB7tBfCg/join

JOIN MY WEEKLY NEWSLETTER http://eepurl.com/inIvGk

Follow me:
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/davidjarthur/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/davearthur
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/justridebikesvideo

videos.title: Size UP or DOWN?  What To Do If You're in BETWEEN Bike Sizes
videos.description:
What should you do if you are in between bike sizes?  Size up or down?  What are the pros and cons of each?
PATREON: https://www.patreon.com/PathLessPedaled
STICKER STORE: https://pathlesspedaled.bigcartel.com/
SHIRTS: https://shop.spreadshirt.com/pathlesspedaled/
INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/pathlesspedaled

Affiliate Links:
Riding Camera: https://www.insta360.com/sal/go_2?insrc=INRNP7I
360 Camera: https://www.insta360.com/sal/one_x2?insrc=INRNP7I
Studio Camera: https://amzn.to/2U9SQiJ
Studio Mic: https://amzn.to/3eehci8
Fave Multitool: https://amzn.to/3ec9ntk
Fave Pump: https://amzn.to/3kd6Any
videos.transcript:
there's probably a pretty good chance
that most of you fall in between a size
range and by that i mean between the
small and the medium between a medium
and a large i personally am a medium and
this really makes bike purchasing really
complicated because you definitely don't
want to buy the wrong size bike because
you've spent all this money there's a
bike shortage what are you going to do
in this video i'm going to share with
you some things i've learned
being in between sizes to help you guys
make a better bike purchasing decision
okay behind me i've got two bicycles i
have a crest bambora in size small and a
bear claw thunderhawk in their size 52.5
which would be the equivalent of a crest
bamboor in size medium i brought these
two bikes out because it'll give you a
good sense of what to expect if you size
down as opposed to sizing up one of the
big challenges of sizing is body
proportions not everybody's bodies are
proportioned the same way so for example
i'm 5 8 which is a pretty average height
for a male in the united states however
my inseam length is 29 inches so that
means i have the legs of a much shorter
person one of the old rules of thumb of
bike sizing is standover height so you
know what that is you
prop the bike up you throw a leg over
and you make sure that you can lift the
bike up and there's some clearance and
that works if you have normal height to
leg ratio but i do not so even on the
size small i don't have the recommended
standover clearance and this has been
kind of the bane of my
bike riding experience i tended to put
more weight over standover clearance and
because of that i tend to
size down when i'm stuck in between two
frames which is pretty much all the time
the downside however of doing this is
you do end up
with a lot more spacers
under your stem i mean personally this
doesn't bother me a whole lot but but
for some it might and some people just
feel compelled to point out the number
of spacers below your stem so that's why
recently
when i purchased the bearclaw
thunderhawk i bought a size up a 52.5
which when you compare it on bike
insights is pretty close to the
medium-sized bamboora the end result of
that is that i'm running fewer spacers i
think the bike generally looks a little
bit more balanced the downside however
is again because of my
short legs to my height ratio i have
like zero standover in fact this is kind
of gently prodding me upwards when i
step when i straddle the bike so you can
see it's a balancing act between
standover height and enough stack so
you're not running like a ton of spacers
and reach so you're not running a super
stubby stem so reach is this horizontal
measurement and although it's fixed you
do have a fair amount of flexibility
in increasing or decreasing the reach
and and by that i mean you know stem
length your handlebars ad reach as well
as the brake hoods so while reach is
fixed it's actually pretty flexible
stack height however the measurement
that kind of determines how high you can
get your handlebars without putting a
ton of spacers below it is kind of
harder to fudge with first off if you've
got a bike with a carbon steer tube you
probably only want to take it so high
before it gets too dangerous too much
excessive force that might break the
steer tube you have a little bit more
latitude with height with an alloy steer
tube if you really want to get your
handlebars high definitely look for a
fork with an alloy steerer tube not a
carbon one so back to stack and reach in
terms of frame size so here i'm looking
at the crest bambora in size small and
medium and just isolating stack and
reach and what's interesting is that
between the two sizes even though you
went up a full size that reach number
only increased by four millimeters but
the stack increased by 23 millimeters so
what that tells me is that if you like
to have your handlebars in a fairly
upright position it might be worthwhile
considering sizing up again in that
example you gain over 20 mil of stack
you can run less spacers the bike's
going to look a little bit better
proportioned you will have to kind of
negotiate that standover height issue
however so let's look at the geocharts
for the bombora and the bear club as you
can see the reach difference between the
small bambora and the 52.5
bear claw again increased by just the
tiniest bit at 3.4 millimeters the stack
however increased to 17 millimeters so
almost 20 ml and you can kind of see how
that plays out in the build fewer
spacers in the front slightly less seat
post showing in the rear like i
mentioned earlier however
i have no standover room on the bear
club but i'm okay with it i'm okay with
it and this is why so for me i'm going
to treat the bear claw mostly as a all
road bikes and be riding paved roads
gravel roads and because it is an
all-road bike i think standover is less
of an issue
unlike would say a mountain bike or a
drop bar mountain bike where i'm going
to be taking it on more single track or
technical terrain where i may have to
put a foot down really quickly that's
when i would want more standover height
however since it's mostly going to be
like a road bike for the vast majority
of time i probably won't be dabbing my
foot or having to put a foot down very
quickly that's a compromise i made with
this bike and i'm completely okay with
it if you're going to be riding a bike
on generally non-technical terrain and
won't have to do super quick dismounts
then then sizing up might be okay this
is the size medium of the tumbleweed
stargazer and there's a couple things
going on here first
you can see here i have fewer spacers
than i have on the bear claw and that is
because this bike has a lot of stack to
it so that means it makes it really easy
to get the handlebars nice and high if
that's what you want one way you can
mitigate this whole standover issue
thing if you're going on technical
terrain with with a bike that is
slightly larger is if you look for a
bike with a sloping top tube this would
buy you some of that stand over
clearance that you don't get with a
horizontal top tube bike so while i'm
pulling random bikes out of the garage
i'm gonna talk about one more thing
which i'm sure someone will ask
is
what do you do
if
you're gonna be using an alt bar that
sweeps back
if you look at the drop bar bike you
know clearly you've got a stem moving
forward and then the handlebar that
pushes you forward still and then your
shifters with a flat bar bike or an all
bar bike you can see that the handlebars
are going to be working to move you
backwards and to counteract this
typically you'll have to run a really
long stem so this is 120 and you might
also have to raise the bars
a fair bit to get it comfortable what
does all this mean in the size
discussion if you're stuck between two
sizes and you're going to run a sweat
back bar definitely choose the larger
size this will help with the reach a
little bit but definitely the stack
height so to summarize if you're in
between
sizes and if you value standover height
over anything else then size down
however if you know that you're going to
want to raise your handlebars you know
fairly level with the saddle if not a
little bit taller then consider sizing
up you'll run fewer spacers granted
you'll lose that standover height but in
the long run it will make it easier to
get the bars up if you're going to be
doing lots of technical riding where you
have to get off really quickly that may
be not a good idea look for a bike with
a sloping top tube or if you're like me
and you know that bike is going to be
used mostly on road and you've made the
piece of sacrifice and stand over height
for a better stack number then size up
hopefully this video was helpful and not
too confusing let me know your
experiences if you're caught between
sizes do you size up or do you size down
who else is this medium puts medium in
the comments i'd love to know if you
like this content consider supporting
the channel by joining us on patreon
that is the best way it gives us a
budget so we can make two videos every
single week like clockwork plus you also
get some awesome perks from lots of
brands that we work with as always
everybody keep the supple side down

videos.title: My FIRST EVER Gravel Race was...HARD (FULL Rasputitsa Gravel Race Story)
videos.description:
I did my first ever gravel race in Vermont at the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race. IT WAS INSANE! MUD, RAIN, COLD, SNOW...It had it all! I had an absolute BLAST even though I thought I was going to lose my fingers.

Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race is a 40mi mud race in Bruke Vermont. There is lots of backcountry gravel roads with 2 very technical sections. Almost 2,000 people were registered for the race so it was full gas form the gun. 

Clifbar brought my coach Tony from ATP Coaching and my self out to the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race to see what its all about. It did not disappoint! Gravel racing is so much fun as its a great mix between fools gas racing and having fun on a bike. 

Really hope you enjoy the full story of my first ever gravel race at the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race. Race Starts at 7:15 Strava route here (https://www.strava.com/activities/2323609317)

/////Hella sick Shirts n stuff
https://www.ridebikesbro.com

https://sp2life.com/pages/vegan-cyclist - code Vegan for 30%off

https://www.patreon.com/thevegancyclist

/////Diamondback deal
Create an account and use crop code VEGAN for INSANE deals
https://www.diamondback.com/partner



follow me bruh
https://www.facebook.com/theVeganCyclist
https://www.strava.com/athletes/180549
https://www.instagram.com/the_vegan_cyclist/

videos.title: Gravel Racing is HARD! (Full Race Breakdown - Belgian Waffle Ride Utah)
videos.description:
This is the full race recap of my effort at the belgian waffle ride in Cedar City Utah. I walk you through the whole race, breakdown each sector, and give you my cycling commentary as the gravel race plays out.   

The belgian waffle ride has a mission to be known as the hardest one day bike races in North America, and this gravel race in Cedar City, Utah lives up to that goal. This gravel race had one of the best courses ive ever ridden. It wasn't too difficult so if you had good base fitness and bike handling skills, you felt pretty competitive for a while. 

BIKE SETUP : 
Bike - Canyon Grail
Wheels - IRC double cross 38s on Princeton carbonworks rims
Gearing - 2x 50/34 - 11/40
Road Shoes and pedals 

NUTRITION: 
(What I started with)
x2 cups of coffee
600 calories in SIS gels
900 calories in bottles
x2 30g bottles of ketones (should be illegal)  
(What I got on the road)
2 waters
4 SIS gels
1 Cliff Block

STRAVA
https://www.strava.com/activities/4208272197/analysis

Check out Dylan and his top 5 finish here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ri8mtN5O-0o

DAILY VLOG VIDEOS: 
Day 1 - https://youtu.be/4SYlO9PmVNs
Day 2 - https://youtu.be/f_8AO3wAGIQ
Day 3 - https://youtu.be/uWI7UF6inKU
Day 4 - https://youtu.be/FGH5k1SO5bk

//////www.Whoop.com /
https://bit.ly/2UXZ8zN follow this link and use code "vegan15" to get 15% off any membership

//////The best kits in the world
www.ElielCycling.com - code veganbro10

/////Hella sick Shirts n stuff
https://www.ridebikesbro.com

/////Recovery Shakes
https://kyoku.com/ (Code "thevegancyclist" for 15% off)

follow me bruh
https://www.facebook.com/theVeganCyclist
https://www.strava.com/athletes/180549
https://www.instagram.com/the_vegan_cyclist/

#gravelracing #cycling #bikeracing #gravelbike

videos.title: Highway 176 Alabama 5/24/2016
videos.description: I decided to take a little detour on my way back. I talked to a man and wife on a Can-Am on the way up and they told me about this road. It is a beautiful ride and very, very curvy. The only thing I didn't like is there are a lot of blind curves and hills that prevent you from seeing what is ahead or oncoming vehicles. But as you will see from the video, other cars aren't a problem. At least not this day. I'm also going to upload the full video I hope. But it is a lot longer. This is just a snippet and you can actually hear me scrape the peg (only my third time ever) in one of the turns toward the end. ...the2:15 mark. Hope you enjoy it.
